final_answer.precision_note: Key inputs are 3 s.f. (0.150 mol dm-3, 23.40 cm3, 25.00 cm3); report concentration to 3 s.f.

method: Convert the NaOH titre to dm3: 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3. Use c = n/V to get moles of NaOH: n(NaOH) = cV = 0.150 × 0.02340 = 0.00351 mol. From H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O, 2 mol NaOH neutralize 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351/2 = 0.001755 mol. Convert acid volume: 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Then c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755/0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: Because 2 mol NaOH react per 1 mol H2SO4 and the volumes are similar, the acid concentration should be a bit under half the NaOH concentration; 0.0702 is slightly under 0.075 and is plausible.
